title: Deputy Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: The entire process took Too long - took over 6 months for them to complete all the interviews and come back to me with offer and even then they were not coordinated
Interview Questions: Basic, simple, questions around leadership

title: Senior Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions: I did seven interviews with different members of the team covering a broad range of topics. Interviews were very cordial and relevant for the position. It was great to have the opportunity to speak with such a broad base of the team.
Interview Questions: What was I most proud of?

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Apr 2023
Interview Descriptions: The process started off with the HM questioning why I would think I even belonged at the Foundation, due to my "confusing" background. I have a very diverse work history. She said "hopefully" I can figure out what it is I want to do. I was surprised I was moved to the final round of interviews after this. The final round consisted of 5 interviews lasting 30-45 mins. The hiring team was fine, but at times implied they were better and smarter than I was. I did my best to answer their questions with real examples and followed the STAR method. I followed up with the recruiter multiple times over 3 weeks with no reply. Finally, a manager reached out to me to let me know that particular recruiter didn't work there anymore, and I wasn't selected to move forward anyway. I would never interview here again after the way I was treated by recruiting and this particular hiring team in general. I wasted a lot of time and energy to be treated as "less than" by the hiring team and ghosted by recruiting.
Interview Questions: How do you prioritize tasks?

title: Senior Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (New Delhi) in Apr 2023
Interview Descriptions: Application on the Job Portal followed by short screening call by the recruiter and 45 min interview with the hiring manager. Both the interviews were based on the CV and hardly any technical questions.
Interview Questions: Describe the situation where the escalation on a teammate is needed?

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: I applied through the Gates' Foundation website. A recruiter contacted me and arranged an interview. The recruiter stated to contact them at the beginning of the year as they were shutting down at the end of the year. I contacted the recruiter who stated that they would get back to me. I contacted them again a couple of weeks later and, again, they stated they'd get back to me. They never did. Ghosted.
Interview Questions: The typical screening questions concerning experiences.

title: Human Resources Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: I went thru 9 interviews only to then receive a copy & paste from rejection letter from the Recruiter that was auto sent at 3a.m. I expected a higher caliber of feedback given the process took over 3 months, and I interviewed with every member of the HR Team as well as those who would be clients. From my candidate side, no one seemed to be on the same page and there were indicators of in fighting between previous, or maybe current, people on the HR team. Numerous interviewers emphasized that there was high turnover and a lot of change, but that "things are getting better".
Interview Questions: Tell me a time you dealt with a difficult client and what was the outcome. Tell me a time you had to use influence with a client and what was the outcome. How do you keep yourself organized. How do you work with a team. How do you build trust with your coworkers and pull your weight in group projects.

title: Strategy Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: They took a while to get back to me but it was a straight forward process, with a screen, then first round, and then a panel. It was a long process though.
Interview Questions: What would your boss say about you in three words?

title: Senior Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions:
When you have to give around 8 interviews for a role, it means that you expect the interviewee to invest a lot of time in the process. It is disappointing then when you come across interviewers that don’t have the right domain knowledge or haven’t even read your CV properly. While some of the people who interviewed me asked technical and relevant questions, others did not. In fact I spent one whole interview trying to convince the interviewer why the cause was important.
At the end of investing so much time and effort I wrote a thank you email to the hiring manager but wasn’t even given the courtesy of a response. Never applying to this company again!
Interview Questions: Case study question asking me to analyse data related to my domain

title: Senior Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Nov 2022
Interview Descriptions: The interview process is one-on-one vs a panel on people. The employees were very personable and the interviews very conversational. Everyone was incredibly energizing and friendly. You can tell everyone is there for because they truly care about the mission and want to make a difference.
Interview Questions: How do you help build a team culture?

title: Human Resources Role Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Nov 2022
Interview Descriptions:
I had a video screening with the recruiter a week before Thanksgiving. The recruiter appeared distracted/bored during the interview and they eventually just turned off their video halfway through the call. They were also dressed in very unprofessional attire for an interview and interrupted me on nearly every question. They ended the conversation saying they would connect via email on next steps the following week.  I have yet to get that email. After following up twice over the course of a month, I gave up. 

The Gates Foundation is a dream company, with an amazing mission, and considered a best place place to work. My interview experience fell way below that bar and my expectations. Do better.
Interview Questions: Tell me a time when you worked with a difficult leader. What was the outcome?

title: Deputy Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Aug 2022
Interview Descriptions: Amable, informativa, muy dispuesta y abierta a dudas. Preguntas adicionales a las típicas de tu perfil. Por ejemplo en Que área del puesto podría requerir apoyo adicional o fortalecimiento? Es la primera entrevista así que es más abierta y ofrecen también información del proceso interno etc.
Interview Questions: Es la primera entrevista,’ preguntaron áreas de fortalezas, que área requeriría más apoyo, como me intereso o que sabía de la Fundacion y que creo es una área de la Fundacion que requiere más atención.

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Aug 2022
Interview Descriptions: Many rounds of behavioral interviews and a slow process overall. Expect at least 2 months for most interview processes. Overall friendly interviewers who are on the hiring team and standard behavioral questions.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you had to solve a problem creatively?

title: Associate Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: They do not often provide visas to international applicants and do not make this clear in the postings.  Check before applying.  Interview is easy.  Be prepared to answer why you are drawn to the Foundation.
Interview Questions: They do not often provide visas to international applicants and do not make this clear in the postings.  Check before applying.  Interview is easy.  Be prepared to answer why you are drawn to the Foundation.

title: Portfolio Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: Archaic. There was more concern with interviewers sharing their sets of experiences and ivy-league education than with clearly communicating or leading effective conversations. Some interviewers communicated clear disdain for internal processes
Interview Questions: Many multi-tiered questions were asked

title: Business Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Apr 2022
Interview Descriptions: Doing an online video interview. A good experience to enhance the interview skill and learned about the detail of the company. Doing an online video interview. A good experience to enhance the interview skill and learned about the detail of the company.
Interview Questions: Please tell us about yourself.

title: People Relations Manager/Human Resources Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions:
First interview with recruiter, hiring manager and upon passing those rounds, full interview of 6-8 interviews. Roughly a full day of interviews.

Provided a good context of role, culture and environment.
Interview Questions: What is your process for identifying and overcoming bottlenecks in your projects?

title: Senior Strategy Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Jan 2022
Interview Descriptions: Organized! Received agenda in advance as well as details on who would be performing the agenda. Prior to the day of meetings, there were 2 screening calls, and ended with another call with the hiring manager.
Interview Questions:
- why I want the job 
- why I want to work for the Foundation
- Experience with DEIB

title: Senior Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions: First interview with a recruiter and then a series of 3 interviews with increasing management individuals. They warn you the interview process is decently awkward due to a list of highly regulated questions. They are fairly basic questions mostly pertaining to how you handle change, initiative, and a flexible work environment. I reciprocated by asking about company culture and discussing working in a highly matrixed environment with a high degree of autonomy. They are really open to answering questions, but interviews are very time sensitive.
Interview Questions: Can you describe a time where you had a give someone the benefit of the doubt? Please be specific.

title: Senior Program Officer, Health Systems Design, India Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Nov 2021
Interview Descriptions:
The hiring team has scant regard for the candidate's time investment.  I was requested to accommodate the hiring manager's work schedule during the festive season whilst I was visiting family. Despite promises to the contrary, the talent acquisition partner took over three weeks to revert citing inability to connect with the interviewer due to competing engagements and different timezones. The final email from her didn't include any feedback on interview specifics, just a stock rejection stating they had decided to go a different direction.

My interview with the hiring manager, which was supposed to be highly technical  (per the HR partner) appeared to be a rehash of my resume and almost too focused on gleaning my life story rather than delving into health systems design nuances.  The interviewer was more focused on my choice of universities and whether those were pedigreed enough. The conversation was neither thoughtful nor health systems development centred, as I had hoped it would be. In some cases, I found the questions somewhat patronising and rather sexist. All in all, it was a colossal waste of time.

As an aside, the interviewer was rather inarticulate. I was somewhat taken aback that he referred to my varied experience of living, studying and working around the world as having a 'chequered' past (?!), which has unflattering connotations. I am not sure they intended this but was shocked to see such mediocrity helming the Foundation, and this experience has certainly diminished my estimation of it as a prospective employer.
Interview Questions: Was your move back from the US to India a case of following your husband around?

title: Senior Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions: Conversational style interviews with 5 different team members spread over 4, 1 hour interviews. Very friendly and inviting. No curveballs, just open discussion of relevant experience and lots of opportunities to ask questions.
Interview Questions: What would be a challenge for you in this role?

title: Senior Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: Several rounds of interviews, including with HR, the hiring manager, team members, and a “final round” interview. The interviews were dynamic and varied, and questions/responses were thoughtful. Going through the process does take time and energy, but there was clear and helpful communication about what to expect or do at each step. Also, everyone I talked to seemed to care about the issues/work, so regardless, it was a set of good conversations. Positive experience overall.
Interview Questions: Can you tell me about the proudest moment in your career? How about when you had to navigate a tough situation?

title: Senior Financial Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: Very long (+4  month) process with multiple rounds, some taking almost 6-8 hours. It was a little off putting how they seemed relatively insensitive to the candidates own time investment in the process
Interview Questions: What management style works best for you and why?

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Jul 2021
Interview Descriptions:
This was the longest interview process I've ever had in my career. Each pause between communication from the recruiter was so long that each time I had forgotten that I had applied for the position. There was some serious turnover and dysfunction at the leadership level at that group and they had to farm out the recruiting and interview process to a third party company.

So at one point, I had decided to maintain communication with the recruiter because I was actually more curious as to where this 7+ month interviewing process was leading to - than the job itself! (And I was actually about to accept another offer but I really wanted to see where this was headed toward)

There was a take home assignment as a starting point for the evaluation. They give you a week to finish it, but I was able to finish it in 2-3 days on and off between downtime and evenings. It was actually kind of interesting.
Interview Questions: Take home assignment testing skills in basic SW development cycle tasks and data analysis.

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: I was an external candidate who interviewed for a LTE position. My interview with the hiring manager and her team went smoothly. However, another internal candidate came in at the last minute and they decided to go with that candidate.
Interview Questions: Tell us about yourself and why are you interested in this role.

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Jun 2021
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted by the recruiter after I submitted an online application and had a 45-minute phone interview with the recruiter. Then, I was invited for 30-minute interview with the hiring manager.
Interview Questions: What was your most challenging project?

title: Associate Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: I had a 7 hour interview with 8 people. It was really intense and designed to really get to the heart of the applicant. It was also very technical. During the interview I was often told that the position that I applied for was a couple positions below my current job at the time. Nevertheless, it was a great opportunity to get into the donor side of development work.
Interview Questions: How do you decide to solve problems when money is no longer a limiting barrier?

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed for six rounds before being informed that the position I applied for was being cut and will no longer be filling that position even though I was likely going to receive an offer. Great way to add insult to injury. I was also surprised with a writing exercise that I was requested to complete a week before my final interview that really threw me off guard, wished my recruiter or the hiring manager would have given me a notice early in my interview process about a 90-minute writing exercise before asking a candidate to complete a critical writing assessment over Memorial Day Weekend.
Interview Questions: Various questions on racial equity/DEI and technical skills.

title: Senior Program Officer Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions: I applied online. Received email from recruiter. Did a screening interview with recruiters. Then a series of interviews with Programs, Communication and Advocacy staff. Finished off interviews with Directors. Overall great experience. Courteous, engaging and thoughtful conversations.
Interview Questions: How does my experience align with the Foundation

title: HR Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was extensive, with a phone interview with recruiter and hiring manager.  The final round included 4-5 rounds of interviews (group) and three 1:1s with a variety of HR team members.
Interview Questions: How would you apply systems knowledge thinking in this role with process improvements?

title: Senior Programme Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: Lengthy and subjective.  It took  10 interviews and 1 months of waiting and cost me an international call (to add $ to Skype) to Seattle only to be told that my experience is too senior.  The HR partner said that in the end, even though all the interview panels ( direct report, business partners, and the line manager's directorate) voted for me, the hiring manager was unsure.
Interview Questions: How do you measure the impact of installing toilets in remote places of Africa?

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: A few phone screens and an in-person some weeks later. The technical questions were fairly straightforward and the technical folks were very enthusiastic, but the two interviewers who asked business related questions were neither friendly nor seemed interested in being there
Interview Questions: What are acceptable grant endpoints?

title: Summer Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: Process started with interview on campus with HR representative after submitting application. HR rep took notes on preferences for interest areas at the Foundation. Second interview was with prospective managers a few weeks later.
Interview Questions:
How have you dealt with conflict in the workplace?
What do you hope to gain out of this experience?

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Nov 2020
Interview Descriptions: Completion of a short questionnaire, followed by several calls from an HR consultancy service. It was not clear to me that the consultancy service identified the skills required from the posted job description, as the response was that they needed to clarify with the employer what specifics were needed.
Interview Questions: Are you eligible to work in the United States?

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Sept 2020
Interview Descriptions: Very rigorous process. Interviewed with multiple members of the team, both leaders and peers. The process may take several weeks to coordinate due to availability. You will get a mix of both subject matter and leadership questions.
Interview Questions: Why the organization, and why the particular role

title: Grants Position Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: So many zoom interviews and all for a contracts role. This is the Gates Foundation, right? Why soooo many contracts positions.. can you commit to hiring permanent staff? It’s not like your broke, c’mon.  If you want to go through a whole lot of hoops for a temp job when your well through the mid point of your career go for it. Otherwise go somewhere that values you. I won’t apply here again.
Interview Questions: Tell us how your experience and values align with our mission?

title: Senior Technical Advisor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions:
I found the position on LinkedIn, applied to it and sent an inmail to the HR director who posted the position. A couple of weeks later the HR director reached out to me through inmail without even reading my previous message telling me that he came across my profile on LinkedIn and he thinks I am a good fit (I had the same job responsibilities in my current role but on a larger scale and had many years of experience in the same field)
I replied to him, he responded a week or so later asking to schedule a zoom interview.

The zoom interview was so unprofessional. I was dressed business casual for the interview while he showed up wearing a flea t-shirt and baseball hat. He had some family moving in his background all the time. He wasn't really concentrating with the discussion. His questions weren't technical of course because he was just an HR guy, but you can't tell the direction of the questions. It felt like he is just asking random questions. As I was out of the state, he told me that they have a relocation package and offered to give more details but we were running out of time so I told him I have some questions that I think it will be better to invest the time left on them.
He concluded the interview by telling me that he will talk with the hiring manager and get back to me in 4 days. 18 days later I sent him a follow-up email to see how the discussions with the hiring manager went.
He replied a week later telling me that they can't afford the relocation cost and decided to move forward with a local candidate. I told him I wasn't even looking for a relocation reimbursement and reminded him that I told him so during the interview but, of course, he never responded.
Obviously, this wasn't the real reason! And obviously it wasn't a technical reason.. I think their reason is something they can't tell me about. My guessing is that it was something about favoritism or special connections.

Bottom line: unprofessional, unpunctual and nontransparent. The name is big but it is definitely misleading.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your current responsibilities.

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Jun 2020
Interview Descriptions: 5 zoom interviews with various members of the team.  Many of the questions were redundant. Overall fairly straight forward. Unfortunately, tend to go with internal hires or folx in administrative roles.
Interview Questions: How do you prioritize competing tasks?

title: Senior Communications Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Jun 2020
Interview Descriptions: This was a long recruitment process, 4 steps that took about 6 months to complete. First with the recruiter, then hiring manager, then group interviews across the offices. Each interaction was professional, and I felt each person was keen to learn more about me and how I could fit in with the organization and team.
Interview Questions: How would you improve reputation management for the Foundation

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in May 2020
Interview Descriptions: Great experience a little long but was a learning experience. Initially, I thought that it would be a quick process but we had back to back interviews and they took over 4 months. I was waiting for feedback for a long time.
Interview Questions: What made you want to work with  the foundation

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: The process was good, more around the experiences that I have in life. Not too many technical questions but around why you want to join Bill and Melinda Gates foundation.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to join the foundation?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Apr 2020
Interview Descriptions: 3 stages, mostly behavioural questions around previous experience, best and worst project experiences, why are you right for the role. First round with HR, second and third rounds with program managers
Interview Questions: Why Gates? What’s a moment when you failed?

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Mar 2020
Interview Descriptions:
The process was very straight forward, and easy to schedule. The recruiter was very nice and helpful. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation does incredible work. 

Although it wasn't a role I was interested at the time, the recruiter was very understanding.
Interview Questions: What is your communication style?

title: Summer Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Feb 2020
Interview Descriptions: There were two parts to the interviewing process. First was an initial phone interview with a representative currently working for the foundation where they gauged your aptitude for global health work and which teams you would best be suited for. Once passing that, you moved on to a 1:1 interview with the heads of each of the teams they recommended you for. It is the team heads that ultimately offer you a position. I definitely recommend coming prepared with relevant and thoughtful questions since your passion for the subject will set you apart in a pool where everyone has the same education.
Interview Questions: Are you familiar with our mission?

title: Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions: This was a truly bizarre interview. Hiring manager was very responsive but never proved any updates and the timeline provided was off by months. I doubt I’ll ever receive a rejection. Interviewed in August and still no update.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in the job.

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Sept 2019
Interview Descriptions: Spoke with HR originally for a different position, but told them that a programmatic role would be a better fit. He agreed, and had me apply pushing me past the initial phone screening to a 3 round interview which took around 2 hours over skype. In the end, I was their second choice, and their first choice accepted the offer. They wanted me to answer how I specifically kept myself organized, offering more detailed examples than what I had given. The second interview asked VERY obtuse questions that threw me off initially. Just be creative and work through the questions!
Interview Questions: Q: Working at Gates, there are many hats to wear. What are your favorite hats?

title: Senior Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Sept 2019
Interview Descriptions: Overall, shocking experience. While some absolutely wonderful people are currently working at BMGF,  unfortunately, the place is filled with impressive CVs that match highly competitive, aggressive and completely toxic individuals. Such a huge disappointment. Lots of potential if this organization was more selective and hired people who are highly accomplished AND balanced souls.
Interview Questions: The onsite interview with several people was akin to being interrogated; hard-hitting, hostile and one-sided; it was not a 'conversation.'

title: Deputy Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (New Delhi) in Aug 2019
Interview Descriptions: Relatively short, with the interviewer doing more of the talking than I did. The interviewer clearly had a point of view regarding the reform agenda he wanted to push, so I was more in listening mode throughout much of the process.
Interview Questions: How can more pooled health funds be raised to cover health costs for the poor in India

title: Senior Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions:
Patience is required for this long process. 
Scheduled for interview over 2 months after applying. Interview with 4-5 different people, it is exhausting but felt fair. 
Each interviewer focuses on a different topic.
Interview Questions: How would your current coworkers describe you?

title: Graduate Student Summer Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
Interview Descriptions: Two rounds of interviews. The first was a short, general interview at my school. The second was a phone interview with the manager of the specific program I was interviewing for.
Interview Questions: Walk us through your resume.

title: IT Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in May 2019
Interview Descriptions: Applied online and then was contacted by contracted IT HR. Interviewed with the hiring manager we seemed to get along and I thought a clear understanding of the position was established. Next steps was an all day onsite interview with all teams this position would work with. At the end of the day met with Department Head. I sensed when asked once again what my "strategy" would be for the position that I would not be selected. I could only go with the job description and what I learned from the team members. I have had this kind of subjective question which resulted in the same declination before. Wondering if other female/minorities have encountered this tactic.
Interview Questions: What would your strategy be within the first 30 days?

title: Interim Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in May 2019
Interview Descriptions:
To summarize my experience: hurry up and wait. 
I had an initial call with the recruiter, who said they are looking to hire asap. The call took about 15-20 minutes and the recruiter sounded unengaged and uninterested. After two weeks he emailed me that he will be meeting with the hiring manager by the end of the week and will update me after their meeting. The following week I received a request for a phone interview with a team member who had very limited availability, and I was told that the interview had to take place that week since the hiring manager wants to hire some quickly. So I moved things around to accommodate their limited availability. I had a nice call with the team member, who said she will meet with the hiring manager the next day and I should be hearing back from the recruiter by the end of the week.  By the middle of the following week, after I did not hear back from the recruiter, I reached out to him, only to be told that he did not meet with the hiring manager yet and in any way, I shouldn't expect an answer that week because it was employee appreciation week. I was told that the recruiter will reach out to me the following week. Of course, I never heard back from him.
Interview Questions: Basic. Why do you want to work for the foundation, how do you prioritize tasks?

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions: After applying got an email from hr with an intro of manager and to touch back with him for further interview process.. Got a call at an exact time mentioned by Mgr,after two days of the interview I received an rejection email. Not sure what they are looking for as I got rejected for the skills neither mentioned in JD nor asked in interview
Interview Questions: Info about Academic and work exp

title: QA Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in May 2019
Interview Descriptions:
This place is super unorganized. They will waste your time with multiple interviews and then decide that they want to go a different direction. Do not interview for this company since they don’t care about your time and do not value people. 

Not only will they waste your time with interviews, they will require you to take a skills test.
Interview Questions: The different between joins

title: Accountant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions: The process was very fair and fast and did not waste anyone's time. They got to the point quickly and asked only questions that were to get to know me and how I think and act in varous situatons. It was fun and would do it a gain.
Interview Questions: How to sell a pen was a question where they wanted to see if I could create interest with such a simple thing as a pen. I think it is an often used question

title: Senior Salesforce Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions: I had two phone screens (one with the recruiter, and one with the hiring manager) before being brought in for an on site interview. The day of my interview they changed my schedule from 4 interviews to two, one being a 4 person panel to interview me. I didn't necessarily mind this, but it was a bit jarring to not be aware until that morning that the schedule would be so different. The interview went well, and I received one follow up by the recruiter a week later about the timing of the decision. title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Apr 2011
Interview Descriptions: I first heard from a recruiter about two weeks after applying online. I emailed a contact I have there as soon as I applied, and I think the referral I got from her helped me to get through the resume screening process (the recruiter later told me they had hundreds of applicants for the position). The recruiter set up a time to talk to me and told me to plan for about a 45-minute call. We ended up talking for less than half an hour, and it was all very basic (i.e. questions about my resume and background and lots of time for me to ask questions). She told me I would hear back the next week and the following week I got an email to set up a time to talk to the hiring manager. This conversation was around 45 minutes and was more questions about my resume and experience. A few days after that I heard from a different recruiter who set up a time for me to come in, and I spent four hours at the Foundation the following week (this is now a month after the initial contact). I spoke to the people I will be working with as well as higher-level people and the recruiter. Most of the questions were again about my background, and everyone I spoke to gave me time to ask questions as well. This is not an interview where anyone will try to trick you, and it's much more about making sure the person they hire is a good fit and is dedicated to the mission of the organization. It was overall a good experience and I would recommend focusing on why you are qualified and what you can bring to the position.
Interview Questions: How do you see your career progressing?

title: IT - Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in Dec 2010
Interview Descriptions:
I was pleasantly surprised at how well I was treated during the interview process.  They were very gracious in all e-mail to me, thanking me for considering employment there.  Given the recent economy and some people still not working, they treated me like I was considering them more than the other way around.

I had a recruiter phone interview first.  Very nice woman and we had a good conversation.  (Now that I'm with the company, we still keep in touch.)  We discussed my past experience and qualifications.  Normal first interview type of questions.  At the end of that call, she discussed the salary and the benefits.  That was helpful.  I had been working at a for-profit for 14 years and thought I would be offered less money.  I was very surprised to find that I would be making at least as much, if not more at the Gates Foundation. Plus, the benefits are amaziningly better and there's a pension contribution that is given (not based on tenure or job level).

Next, I was set up for all day interviews.  I was actually being considered for 2 different jobs.  I interviewed with 6 people that day in a conference room.  They very nicely had me pre-order lunch but I was in the conference room all day w/ no breaks.  Even my lunch was an interview.  I didn't eat much as it is awkward to interview and eat (plus, I would have no doubt gotten something stuck in my teeth and that was not the impression I wanted to leave w/ anyone!).

I knew my chances were very good after that series of interviews.  I rec'd good feedback and thought I had a good showing.  However, I did go back for 2 more interviews late on a Friday afternoon.  It was to meet the director of the dept and a person who would be my co-worker (who wasn't available during the first round).

Again, things went well and I thought I might hear next steps the following week.  I was blown away when the recruiter called my cell phone before I had even arrived home.  I called her back and she verbally gave me the job offer on a Friday night at 6:30pm!  Throughout my experiences, everyone was really great, respectful, and complimentary. 

The only thing that gave me pause was what I was hearing through my background research (I knew people who had contracted with the Foundation) and even existing employees mentioned this during the interview.  That is, that it can be a hard place to work and to get things done.  The reasons mentioned were that it is still a young company, working on process and organizational maturity.  I see that is true now that I'm here.  However, it's also exciting to be part of that building process.  It has a bit of a start-up feel.  People are really passionate and want to make a difference.  Both in the world through the Foundation's mission, but also at the company.  If you'd like to join a company where you can be part of the creative input to the processes, systems, and culture, you may like it here!
Interview Questions: Pretty basic interview questions for my role.  How would I handle this situation or give me an example of a time when you worked on...

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Seattle, WA) in May 2010
Interview Descriptions: Initial phone w/ HR, followed by phone w/ hiring manager. 1:1 you sit in a room while people come to you. I ate lunch alone, in the room (it was explained that they seem to think that people like a breather to be on their own. er, lunch w/ potential co-workers is where you get a real sense of what it is like to work there.. so that was concerning). You do not get to see where you will work, or who co-workers are aside from those involved in the interview. Interview Qs depended upon the person, but for the most part clearly untrained in determining best fit. A few illegal Qs thrown in, but I think these were ignorance over intentional fact finding. Major attitude w/ junior peers, which is to be expected, I suppose. Not one person could clearly explain how things work or identify specific projects or tasks- everything described in a vague sort of way. I got the distinct sense that decisions are not made easily, or by any specific person or persons. The environment described as collegiate, but seems more like "under managed" is more accurate. Initial follow up emails were not responded to (probably because I wasn't going to be offered the job, but still. "nice to meet you, too" - is that so difficult?). I don't think they would've bothered to tell me that I wasn't going to be offered the position if I hadn't been diligent about following up. My criticisms are not coming from bitterness- to be honest, if I had been offered the job it would've been a difficult decision. Something was not right, and I got the feeling that I was not given an accurate picture of what the job really entailed (despite direct questioning) or what the environment was really like- it was like talking to politicians. To turn down an opportunity to work at Gates would've been major... I probably would've taken it and been miserable within a month.....so in the end best outcome...
Interview Questions: Do you get along with all types of managers? What managing style do you prefer?
